text: on March 7 2009 the Kepler space
telescope was launched with the sole
mission of searching a thumbnail sized
portion of the sky containing a hundred
and fifty thousand stars for planets the
data are in and are being analyzed and a
group of scientists has determined that
our galaxy contains billions of
earth-like planets
okay so stars are really really far away
we can only see them because they are
supermassive fusion-powered light
generators so the idea that we can see
or rather detect the planets around them
is kind of not so like it was
unthinkable 20 years ago but it turns
out we can do it and there are a number
of ways to do it but Kepler does it by
measuring the extremely faint dimming of
a star as a planet passes in front of it
Kepler can tell basically two things it
can tell how much the star is dimmed and
how long it takes for the planet to come
back around to dim the star again from
those two data points we can infer some
wonderfully useful things from the
amount the star is dimmed we can
determine the diameter of the planet and
from the length of the orbit we can
determine how close the planet is to the
star we can figure out that last thing
by the way using a mathematical formula
figured out in the 1600s by you guessed
it Johannes Kepler and the most recent
news here is that a group of scientists
wanted to use Kepler's excellent data to
figure out how rare earth-like planets
are here's how they did it first you
pick out only sun-like stars since we
don't really know how planets around
bigger or smaller stars would function
there were 46 thousand of these in the
sample second analyze the data for just
those stars they found six hundred and
three planets now narrow it down to the
planets that are roughly the size of
Earth and orbit in a zone where water
can exist and voila ten earth-like
planets were observed by Kepler now how
do we get to billions from ten well
Kepler can only detect planets that pass
between their stars and the telescope
like if you're the dose go put on the
star only if the planet is passing here
can you actually detect it and it's a
tiny little speck compared to the star
to be clear all that other space like if
the planet is rotating just like just up
here you never see it cross in front of
the star so the fact that it happened
even ten times indicates that in fact
there are tons of earth-like planets
since the orientation of solar systems
in the galaxy is random we
can take this into account and find that
in fact about 22% of the planet surveyed
had earth-like planets they just weren't
including the star extrapolating this
over all of the 20 billion sun-like
stars in our galaxy and yes billions of
earths
of course to be clear all of those
earths are unreachable distant but since
just 20 years ago contemplating even
detecting them was unthinkable maybe
we're not so far off the next step of
course is to get a fancy telescope up
there that could detect the atmospheric
composition of some of these planets
some scientists argue that a high
percentage of oxygen in the atmosphere
around the planet would pretty much
guarantee that there was life operating
on it answering one of the deepest
questions of human existence though
honestly with the pool billions of
Earth's deep in this galaxy alone I
cannot imagine that life hasn't sprung

what I would give to be the guy who
